title: 110_hr36
content: The Act is titled the "National Science Education Tax Incentive for Teachers Act of 2007" and introduces a refundable credit for a portion of tuition paid for undergraduate education of certain teachers. The "National Science Education Tax Incentive for Teachers Act of 2007" offers a tax credit of 10% of qualified undergraduate tuition paid by eligible teachers, up to $1,000. For teachers in high-needs school districts, the credit can be up to $1,500 in the first 5 years of eligibility. The tax credit for eligible teachers can be up to $1,500 in the first 5 years, and $1,000 thereafter for a total of 10 years. Eligible teachers must be full-time teachers in grades K-12, teaching math, science, engineering, or technology courses. Eligible teachers must teach math, science, engineering, or technology courses in grades K-8, have a relevant degree, and be highly qualified. School administrative functions related to these courses are also eligible for the tax credit. The text discusses qualified undergraduate tuition for enrollment at an institution of higher education, as defined in the Higher Education Act of 1965. The Secretary will prescribe regulations to carry out the purposes of this section. Conforming amendments are also mentioned in relation to title 31, United States Code. The text discusses amending section 1324(b) of title 31, United States Code, and the table of sections for subpart C of part IV of subchapter A of chapter 1 of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The amendments made by this section apply to taxable years beginning after the enactment of this Act, with only eligible teachers defined in section 36(c) of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986 taken into account under section 36(b)(3) of the Code.
